rocks.bastion.core.json

Class JsonResponseAssertions

  • java.lang.Object
    • rocks.bastion.core.json.JsonResponseAssertions
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Assertions<Object>

    public class JsonResponseAssertions
extends Object
implements Assertions<Object>
    Performs assertions on a response by checking for status code and content-type. The user supplies a JSON string that will act as the expected body of the response. Bastion will then compare the actual received JSON string with the user-supplied expectation. The comparison will not be a straight-up string equality check though: Bastion will interpret the JSON of both the expected body and the actual response body and perform a structural comparison. This is important, because the JSON specification says that a JSON object is unordered and we do not want a different order of properties to fail the assertion.
    Author:
    Kyle

    • Method Detail

      • fromString

        public static JsonResponseAssertions fromString(int expectedStatusCode,
                                                String expectedJson)
        Creates a JsonResponseAssertions object which expects the specified response HTTP status code and the specified JSON. The supplied JSON must be syntactically correct; otherwise, an exception is thrown to indicate that the expected JSON string is invalid.
        Parameters:
        expectedStatusCode - The expected HTTP status code
        expectedJson - The expected JSON object
        Returns:
        An assertions object for use with the AssertionsBuilder.withAssertions(Assertions) method
        Throws:
        InvalidJsonException - Thrown if the given JSON text is not valid JSON text

      • fromResource

        public static JsonResponseAssertions fromResource(int expectedStatusCode,
                                                  String expectedJsonSource)
        Creates a JsonResponseAssertions object which expects the specified response HTTP status code and JSON, which is loaded from the specified resource. The resource source is specified as a resource URL as described in ResourceLoader. Valid resource URLs include (but are not limited to):
        • classpath:/rocks/bastion/json/Sushi.json
        • file:/home/user/Sushi.json
        For more information about which resource URLs are accepted see the documentation for ResourceLoader.

        The loaded JSON must be syntactically correct; otherwise, an exception is thrown to indicate that the expected JSON string is invalid.

        Parameters:
        expectedStatusCode - The expected HTTP status code
        expectedJsonSource - The resource to load the expected JSON object from
        Returns:
        An assertions object for use with the AssertionsBuilder.withAssertions(Assertions) method
        Throws:
        InvalidJsonException - Thrown if the loaded JSON text is not valid JSON text
        UnreadableResourceException - Thrown if the specified resource exists but cannot be read (because it is a directory, for example)
        ResourceNotFoundException - Thrown if the specified resource does not exist

      • fromTemplate

        public static JsonResponseAssertions fromTemplate(int expectedStatusCode,
                                                  String expectedJsonSource,
                                                  Map<String,String> variableAssignments)
        Similar to the fromResource(int, String) method but also supports template variable assignments. This allows you to store an expected JSON object's template as a JSON file where the template is written using Mustache. Each variable's value is supplied as the variableAssignments parameter in a map. If the template cannot resolve a variable, an exception is thrown.

        The template file is specified as a resource URL as described in ResourceLoader. Valid resource URLs include (but are not limited to):

        • classpath:/rocks/bastion/json/Sushi.json
        • file:/home/user/Sushi.json

        For more information about which resource URLs are accepted see the documentation for ResourceLoader.

        The loaded JSON, after variables are resolved, must be syntactically correct; otherwise, an exception is thrown to indicate that the expected JSON string is invalid.

        Parameters:
        expectedStatusCode - The expected HTTP status code
        expectedJsonSource - The resource to load the expected JSON object template from
        variableAssignments - The values used when resolving variables in the loaded template
        Returns:
        An assertions object for use with the AssertionsBuilder.withAssertions(Assertions) method
        Throws:
        InvalidJsonException - Thrown if the loaded JSON text is not valid JSON text
        UnreadableResourceException - Thrown if the specified resource exists but cannot be read (because it is a directory, for example)
        ResourceNotFoundException - Thrown if the specified resource does not exist
        TemplateCompilationException - Thrown if a variable in the loaded template does not have an assignment in the variableAssignments map

      • fromModel

        public static JsonResponseAssertions fromModel(int expectedStatusCode,
                                               Object expectedModel)
        Creates a {@link JsonResponseAssertions} object which expects the specified response HTTP status code and the serialized JSON representation of the specified model. The comparison is made by serializing the provided expected model and comparing the resultant JSON String to the response body's content as with fromString(int, String).
        Parameters:
        expectedStatusCode - The expected HTTP status code
        expectedModel - The model which will be deserialized into the expected JSON object.
        Returns:
        An assertions object for use with the AssertionsBuilder.withAssertions(Assertions) method

      • ignoreValuesForProperties

        public JsonResponseAssertions ignoreValuesForProperties(String... fields)
        Ignore particular fields' values in the actual JSON response. Notice that Bastion will still fail the assertion if a JSON field is missing, is in the wrong place, or is extra. Ignoring fields' values using this method is useful for randomly generated values in the response, such as IDs or timestamps.

        Implementation wise, when performing the JSON patch diff between the expected and the actual responses, Bastion will ignore any patch operations which have op "replace" and a field which is one of the ignored fields.
        Parameters:
        fields - The fields' names to ignore
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining)

      • ignoreOrderForArrayProperties

        public JsonResponseAssertions ignoreOrderForArrayProperties(String... fields)
        Ignore particular array fields' order in the actual response. This means that:
        { "array":["first","second","third"] }
        Will be considered equivalent to:
        { "array":["third","first","second"] }
        It will still detect and report any extra or missing values.

        Implementation wise, when performing the JSON patch diff between the expected and the actual responses, Bastion will ignore any patch operations which have op "move" and a field which is one of the ignored fields.
        Parameters:
        fields - The fields' names to ignore the order of
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining)

      • overrideContentType

        public JsonResponseAssertions overrideContentType(org.apache.http.entity.ContentType contentType)
        The assertions object will initially check that the content-type header returned by the actual response is "application/json". This can be overriden to check for a different content-type header using this method. Despite this, this assertions object will still try to interpret the body as if it were JSON text.
        Parameters:
        contentType - The expected content-type header
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining)

      • execute

        public void execute(int statusCode,
                    ModelResponse<?> response,
                    Object model)
             throws AssertionError
        Description copied from interface: Assertions
        Asserts that the given response, retrieved after Bastion performs an HTTP request, is correct. To indicate that the response did not pass assertions, this method throws AssertionError. Note that this is important because Bastion makes a distinction between a test containing an error (ie. any exception which is not AssertionError) and one which has a failed assertion. This difference will be made visible in a testing framework which is running a Bastion test.
        Specified by:
        execute in interface Assertions<Object>
        Parameters:
        statusCode - The HTTP status code received for the response.
        response - A representation of the HTTP response which was received.
        model - The model object that was created by binding the HTTP response body to an actual Java object.
        Throws:
        AssertionError - Thrown if the HTTP response does not pass the assertions.
